moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 N: This is the mainline Open Sicilian.
moves.6. Be2: This is less aggressive than Bc4 or Bg5.
moves.6... e5: The Boleslavsky Variation of the Open Sicilian.
moves.7. Nf3: This is the modern approach. Nb3 used to be played, but this move restricts the freeing d6-d5 by black, as there is pressure on e5.
moves.9. Re1: He is preparing more pressure down the e file, making d6-d5 harder for black.
moves.9... h6: And I play this at last.
moves.11... a6: Slightly unusual, but common in most variations of the Open Sicilian.
moves.12. Nd5: I was happy with this. Exchanging on d5 covers my weak d6 pawn with his d5 pawn. I don't mind giving White the two bishops, nor a bit more space.
moves.15. b3: He re-enforces his pawns and prepares to develop his bishop to b2 or a3.
moves.15... Ne8: This seems to be a new move in this position, Nh7 or a5 have been tried in the past. I am not sure that my move is any weaker than those moves.
moves.16. Bb2: So he gets his bishop into place.
moves.16... Nc7: Getting ready to expand with b7-b5
moves.17... f5: I strike on the king side. Threat e5-e4
moves.18. Qe2: Now if e5-e4, if I take his knight or bishop he can take my bishop on e7
moves.18... Rf7: So I protect that bishop, making the same threat.
moves.19... b5: This may be a mistake, trying for play on both sides of the board, but I couldn't really see what else to play.
moves.20. Nh2: He prepares to undermine my centre.
moves.21... Kh7: I move to a safer place, off the g file, which is about to open.
moves.23. Kh1: His king goes to a safer spot too, hoping for play with his rooks down the g file.
moves.23... Bg5: So I move my bishop to a more attacking post.
moves.24... Qe7: I get ready to mobilze Ra8
moves.31. Qe3: He protects h3 and attacks g5
moves.34... Nc5: I protect e5. This was the point of me exchanging on c4 - now my knight can't be chased away with b3-b4.
moves.35... Kh6: To make sure he doesn't take with check.
moves.36. Re2: I am not sure why he didn't just take on e5. He was afraid of pins on the e file, but are they really that dangerous. What do you think dear reader?
moves.36... Na8: So I redevelop my worst piece.
moves.37... Kg7: This is a mistake. g6 was better
moves.40. Qg3: He wants to keep control of the f file
moves.42... Qf6: Now if he exchanges queens, my king matches into the centre of the board and wins.
moves.43. Qg2: This is a massive mistake. Simply Kg2 and the position is still level
moves.46... Qf3: I calculate I can give up my knight and queen my pawn.
moves.49. Qe7: I was down to only two minutes now, and moving virtually instantaneously. This is the first win I missed. Queening the pawn with check looks so strong. In fact if I take the h pawn first, I am mating him.
moves.50. Kh2: Now I have no more checks, and he is threatening mate on h7.
moves.51. Qe8+: This is another chance for me to win. Kh6 wins after Qh8 check, Qh7, but, as I explained.....
moves.53. Qe8+: And there is no way to escape the checks. Many thanks for reading this, hope you enjoyed it, please leave a comment or two and rate it on the star system.
